case_name: Trilok Singh and Pala Singh v. State

facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 197 of 1969 is an appeal by special leave under Article 136 of the Constitution against the judgment dated May 15, 1969 of the Punjab and Haryana High Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 197 of 1969. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated May 15, 1969 of the Punjab and Haryana High Court at Chandi- garh in Criminal Appeal No. 385 of 1967.

facts.text: High Court allowed in part the State appeal from the order of Additional Sessions Judge, Jullundur acquitting five accused under sections 302, 302/34, 120B and 302/109 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave under Art. 136 of the Constitution of India is directed against the judgment dated May 16, 1969 of the High Court of Punjab and Haryana allowing in part the State appeal from the order of Shri Kartar Singh, Additional Sessions Judge, Jullundur, acquitting the five accused, charged under ss. 302, 302/34, 120B and 302/109, I.P.C.

facts.text: High Court convicted Trilok Singh under section 302 IPC and Pala Singh under section 302/34 IPC, sentencing both to imprisonment for life.

anchor.surface_text: and companyvicting on appeal Trilok Singh and Pala Singh, appellants,the former under s. 302, P.C. and the latter under S. 302 read with S. 34, I.P.C They were both sentenced to imprisonment for life.

facts.text: Atma Singh purchased a plot of land measuring 58 kanals and 10 marlas in Basti Danish Mandan, Jullundur City in 1959 for about Rs. 16,000 from Government at public auction.

anchor.surface_text: The facts giving rise to this appeal briefly stated are that Atma Singh, resident of Basti Danish Mandan, Jullundur City had purchased a plot of land measuring 58 kanals and 10 marlas in the aforesaid Basti in the year 1959 for a sum of about Rs. 16,000 from the Government at a, public auction.

facts.text: The land was cultivated by Hazara Singh and his associates who were disinclined to give up possession.

anchor.surface_text: This piece of land was at that time being cultivated by Hazara Singh, one of the five companyccused in the trial companyrt and his associates. As they were disinclined to give up possession Atma Singh appointed Ram Singh  P. W. 14  and Sham Singh  Deceased  as his attorneys

facts.text: Ram Singh PW14 and Sham Singh deceased obtained possession of the plot with police and revenue authorities help in June 1963.

anchor.surface_text: These two attorneys obtained possession of the plot with the help of the police and through the intervention of the revenue authorities in June, 1963.

facts.text: Hazara Singh and 7-8 others including Trilok Singh son of Surain Singh (accused 1) and Trilok Singh son of Inder Singh (accused 5) threatened the attorneys with death.

anchor.surface_text: A few days later Hazara Singh and 7 or 8 others persons including Trilok Singh son. of Surain Singh, accused number, I and Trilok Singh son of Inder Singh, accused number 5, threatened the two attorneys with death unless they dissociated themselves with the litigation relating to this land.

facts.text: Land was ploughed by attorneys in presence of police on June 26, 1963; Hazara Singh, Trilok Singh son of Inder Singh and Harnam Singh (father of Pala Singh) came armed with lathis and were apprehended.

anchor.surface_text: The land in question was actually ploughed by the attorneys in the presence of the police on June 26, 1963 when Hazara Singh, Trilok Singh son of Inder Singh and Harnam Singh, father of Pala Singh, came there armed with lathes but were apprehended.

facts.text: Crop on the land found damaged on August 9, 1963; at instance of Ram Singh PW14, police prosecuted Hazara Singh, Tara Singh, Channan and Trilok Singh son of Inder Singh who were convicted.

anchor.surface_text: On August 9, 1963 the crop standing on the said and was found damaged. At the instance of Ram Singh  P.W. 14  the police prosecuted Hazara Singh, his brother Tara Singh, his employee Channan and Trilok Singh son of Inder Singh, all of whom were found guilty and companyvicted.

facts.text: On December 15, 1963 Hazara Singh and 17-18 others attacked Sham Singh deceased and Ram Singh PW14.

anchor.surface_text: On December 15, 1963 Hazara Singh and 17 or 18 other persons attached Sham Singh, deceased, and Ram Singh  P.W. 14 .

facts.text: Sham Singh and Ram Singh were attacked by six persons including Hazara Singh, two Trilok Singhs, Channan Singh, Harnam Singh and Nangal Singh; committed to sessions for offence under s.307 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: During the pendency of these proceedings Sham Singh, deceased, and Ram Singh  P.W. 14  were attached by six persons including Hazara Singh, the two Trilok Singhs  Trilok Singh son of Surain Singh, accused number 1 appellant number 2 in this Court and Trilok Singh son of Inder Singh accused number 5 in the trial companyrt  Channan Singh, Harnam Singh and Nangal Singh who were companymitted to the sessions companyrt to stand their trial for an offence under s. 307, I.P.C. and other offences.

facts.text: The s.307 case was adjourned to June 3, 1966 due to absence of Trilok Singh appellant; Sham and Ram were to appear as prosecution witnesses.

anchor.surface_text: Sham, deceased, and Ram Singh  P.W. 14  were to appear as prosecution witnesses in that case which was adjourned to June 3 1966 because of the absence of Trilok Singh, appellant.

facts.text: On May 23, 1966 at about 7.30 a.m., Trilok Singh appellant (kirpan), Dhira (kirpan), Pala Singh (lathi), Trilok Singh son of Inder Singh (lathi) attacked Sham Singh near Babu Rain's shop.

anchor.surface_text: On May 23, 1966 at about 7.30 a. m. Laxman Singh  P.W.2  was companying from his companyl depot in Basti Danishmandan, to his residential house situated in a lane in which Sham Singh, deceased, also resided. ... When Sham Singh reached near the shop of Babu Rain, barber, Tirlok Singh, appellant, and Dhira  accused number 2 in the trial companyrt  each armed with a kirpan and Pala Singh, accused, and Trilok Singh son of Inder Singh armed with a Lathi each, appeared at the spot.

facts.text: Trilok Singh son of Inder Singh shouted that the enemy had come and should be murdered.

anchor.surface_text: Trilok Singh son of Inder Singh shouted that the enemy had companye and should be murdered.

facts.text: Dhira aimed kirpan blow at head of Sham Singh, who caught it but it was pulled away; Pala Singh gave lathi blow on head causing fall; Trilok Singh gave three or four kirpan blows on back of neck.

anchor.surface_text: Dhira aimed a kripan blow at the head of Sham Singh, deceased, who caught hold of the kirpan but the same was pulled away by Dhira. Pala Singh there upon gave a lathi below on the head of the deceased as a result of which he fell on the ground face downwards. This was followed by three or four kirpan blows by the appellant Trilok Singh on the back of the next of the deceased.

facts.text: Occurrence witnessed by Gokal Chand PW3 and Trilochan Singh PW9.

anchor.surface_text: The occurrence was witnessed by Gokal Chand  P.W.3  who practises in Ayurvedic system of medicine and has a shop nearby and Trilochan Singh  P.W. 9  a tractor driver who happened to pass that way to attend to his duties as such,

facts.text: Additional Sessions Judge acquitted all accused holding prosecution evidence not trustworthy, FIR delayed, inquest tampered, special report delayed.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Additional Sessions Judge acquitted all the ac- cused persons holding that the Assistant Sub-Inspector, Kashmiri Lal, who had investigated the offence had number performed his duties in a fair and straight forward manner and that the prosecution evidence was number trustworthy so as to bring home the offence to the accused beyond the possibility of a reasonable doubt. ... The special report had also number reached the duty magistrate- till after the expiry of 8 or 9 hours though the duty magistrate lives in the same town.

facts.text: High Court considered evidence in detail and concluded prosecution proved case against Trilok Singh and Pala Singh.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal by the State the High Court companysidered the entire evidence in great detail and examined all the material circumstances which had weighed with the trial companyrt in disbelieving the prosecution story, and in disagreement with the trial companyrt, cameto the companyclusion that the prosecution had fully proved the case against the two appellants in this Court.

facts.text: FIR recorded at 9.05 a.m. on May 23, 1966; time of occurrence 7.30 a.m.; distance to PS about 2.4 miles.

anchor.surface_text: The F.I.R. purports to have been recorded at 9.5 a.m. on May 23, 1966. The time of occurrence is stated to be 7-30 a.m. on that very day and the distance between the place of occurrence and the Police Station is about 24 miles.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that there was no undue delay in FIR or investigation, rejected arguments of tampering and delay in special report.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the criticism levelled by Shri Kohli does number justify the rejection of the F.I.R. or of the site plan and the inquest report, as suggested by Shri Kohli. ... We are number persuaded to hold that there is any ground for differing with the companyclusion of the High Court.

facts.text: Appellate court has full power to review evidence and reverse acquittal if not justified.

anchor.surface_text: The companyrt of appeal has full power under the statute to go into the entire evidence and all the relevant circumstances of the case for companying to its own companyclusion about the guilt or innocence of the accused bearing in mind the initial presumption of the innocence of an accused person and the fact that he was acquitted by the trial companyrt.

concepts.unlisted_description: Procedure for investigation report to magistrate

anchor.surface_text: Section 157, Cr. P.C. requires such report to be sent forthwith by the police officer concerned to a magistrate empowered to take cognisance of such offence. This is really designed to keep the magistrate informed of the investigation of such cognizable offence so as to be able to control the investigation and if necessary to give appropriate direction under s. 159.

concepts.interpretation: Purpose to inform magistrate for control/directions; delay not vitiating investigation.

anchor.surface_text: An appellate Court has full powers to review the evidence upon which the order of acquittal is founded 2. the principles laid down in Sheo Swarup's case 61 I.A. 398 afforded a correct guide for the appellate court's approach to a case disposing of such an appeal 3. the different phraseology used in the judgments of this court such as a substantial and compelling reasons b good and sufficiently cogent reasons c strong reasons are not intended to curtail the undoubted power of an appellate court in an appeal against acquittal to review the entire evidence and to come to its own conclusion

issues.text: Whether the High Court was justified in reappraising the evidence for itself and disagreeing with the trial court by convicting the appellants on appeal against acquittal

anchor.surface_text: The principal argument advanced by him in support of this appeal was that the learned Additional Sessions Judge had on a consideration of the entire evidence come to a conclusion which is reasonable and had, on the basis of that conclusion held that the prosecution witnesses were not reliable and that the accused were, therefore, entitled to acquittal. The High Court, according to this submission, was not justified in reapprais

issues.text: Whether the first information report was recorded after a long delay

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, according to this submission, was not justified in reappraising the evidence for itself and in disagreeing with the reasoning of the trail court for convicting the appellants on appeal against acquittal. We would first deal with the argument that the first information report was recorded after a long delay, that the inquest report was tampered with by A.S.I. Kashmiri Lal, and that the special report was not sent to the duty magistrate with the promptitude expected under the Code of Criminal Procedure.

Kashmiri Lal, and that the special report was not sent to the duty magistrate with the promptitude expected under the Code of Criminal Procedure.

issues.text: Whether the special report under s.157 CrPC was sent to the magistrate with promptitude

anchor.surface_text: Shri Kohli strongly criticised the fact that the occurrence report contemplated by S. 157, Cr.P.C. was sent to the magistrate concerned very late. Indeed, this challenge, like the argument of interpolation and belated despatch of the inquest report, was developed for the purpose of showing that the investigation was not just, fair and forthright and, therefore, the prosecution case must be looked at with great suspicion.

issues.text: Whether the insertion of s.120B in the site plan indicates unfair or biased investigation

anchor.surface_text: The second criticism related to the insertion in the site plan of S. 120B which only relates to Hazara Singh, whose name had not been mentioned by anyone up to that stage. From the insertion of S. 120B in the site plan it was inferred that Kashmiri Lal had some enmity with Hazara Singh and that he had, therefore, already made up his mind to falsely rope Hazara Singh in. On this line of. reasoning it was suggested that the investigation carried out by Kashmiri Lal was far from honest, faithful and fair.

holdings.text: The court of appeal has full power under the statute to go into the entire evidence and all the relevant circumstances of the case for coming to its own conclusion about the guilt or innocence of the accused bearing in mind the initial presumption of the innocence of an accused person and the fact that he was acquitted by the trial court.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirms settled principles from Sanwat Singh v. State of Rajasthan, Ramabhupala Reddy, and Sheo Swarup, clarifying that phraseology like 'substantial reasons' does not limit full review power.

holdings.text: plainly the F.I.R. cannot be considered to have been lodged after undue delay. Nor can it be said that dead body of the deceased was despatched from the place of occurrence after undue delay.

anchor.surface_text: If S.I. Pritam Lal reached the place of occurrence at 10 a.m. as deposed by him, which statement is not shaken by any cross-examination then plainly the F.I.R. cannot be considered to have been lodged after undue delay.

holdings.reasoning_summary: FIR recorded at 9:05 a.m., occurrence at 7:30 a.m., distance 2.4 miles; PW13 reached spot at 10 a.m.; unchallenged testimony.

holdings.text: assuming without holding, that in the inquest report the figure 4 and word four were added afterwards, in our view, this by itself does not detract from the general trustworthiness of the inquest report nor does it render the investigation suspicious so as to be fatal to the prosecution.

anchor.surface_text: assuming without holding, that in the inquest report the figure 4 and word four were added afterwards, in our view, this by itself does not detract from the general trustworthiness of the inquest report nor does it render the investigation suspicious so as to be fatal to the prosecution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sent promptly with body; no motive to match medical exactly (expected 5 injuries if tampering); minor discrepancy not fatal.

holdings.text: It cannot, therefore, be said that in the site plan mention of Hazara and of an offence under s. 120B, being a later interpolation, is a suspicious circumstance suggesting unfairness of the investigation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: FIR references Hazara's interest in land; insertion raises slight suspicion but overridden by trustworthy evidence.

holdings.text: however improper or objectionable the delayed receipt of the report by the magistrate concerned it cannot by itself justify the conclusion that the investigation was tainted and the prosecution insupportable.

anchor.surface_text: But when we find in this case that the F.I.R. was actually recorded without delay and the investigation started on the basis of that I.R. and there is no other infirmity brought to our notice, then, however improper or objectionable the delayed receipt of the report by the magistrate concerned it cannot by itself justify the conclusion that the investigation was tainted and the prosecution insupportable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: FIR prompt, investigation proceeded without delay, no prejudice to accused; purpose under ss.157/159 is magistrate oversight, delay not vitiating.

holdings.text: We do not think that the High Court committed any error in the appraisal of the evidence on the record and in arriving at its own conclusion as to the guilt of the appellants.
holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court detailed review disagreed with trial court; prosecution evidence trustworthy despite minor discrepancies; no grave suspicion.

holdings.text: We are not persuaded to hold that there is any ground for differing with the conclusion of the High Court.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No failure to follow Sanwat Singh principles; conclusions not erroneous warranting Art.136 interference; limited scope of special leave appeal.

precedents.citation: Sanwat Singh v. State of Rajasthan 1

anchor.surface_text: Sanwat Singh v. State of Rajasthan 1 . Ramabhupala Reddy v. State of A p.

precedents.case_name: Sanwat Singh v State of Rajasthan
precedents.cited_proposition: Appellate court has full power to review evidence in appeal against acquittal and come to its own conclusion if acquittal not justified
precedents.cited_holding: An appellate Court has full powers to review the evidence upon which the order of acquittal is founded

precedents.cited_proposition: Legal position on scope of appeal against acquittal settled; appellate court must give reasons for disagreeing with trial court acquittal
precedents.cited_holding: the controversy in regard to the scope of an appeal against an order of acquittal has been settled by this Court in Sanwant Singh supra
